item.title: Tracing Back the Malicious Clients in Poisoning Attacks to Federated Learning
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes FLForensics for tracing malicious clients in federated learning poisoning attacks
  • Complements existing training defenses by post-attack analysis
  • Theoretically and empirically validated on benchmark datasets

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

item.title: COMAL: A Convergent Meta-Algorithm for Aligning LLMs with General Preferences
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes COMAL, a meta-algorithm for aligning LLMs with general preferences using a game-theoretic framework
  • Aims to find the Nash equilibrium policy to ensure a 50% win rate against any competing policy
  • Provides theoretical convergence guarantees and empirical evaluations on synthetic and real datasets

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Yixin Liu', 'Argyris Oikonomou', 'Weiqiang Zheng', 'Yang Cai', 'Arman Cohan']
  • Tags: ['alignment', 'game theory', 'Nash equilibrium', 'preference learning', 'reinforcement learning']

item.description:
Summary

item.title: Simulating and Understanding Deceptive Behaviors in Long-Horizon Interactions
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces a simulation framework for evaluating deception in LLMs over long-horizon interactions
  • Uses a multi-agent system with performer, supervisor, and auditor agents
  • Tests 11 models and finds deception increases with pressure and erodes trust
  • Identifies strategies like concealment, equivocation, and falsification

  • Research

item.title: The Silent Judge: Unacknowledged Shortcut Bias in LLM-as-a-Judge
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper studies biases in LLMs used as judges, showing they rely on shortcuts like recency and provenance instead of content quality.
  • It uses ELI5 and LitBench datasets with GPT-4o and Gemini-2.5-Flash models.
  • The models show strong recency bias and provenance hierarchy, with GPT-4o more affected.
  • Justifications rarely mention the injected cues, leading to unreliable evaluations.

Paper Type

  • Research Paper

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Arash Marioriyad', 'Mohammad Hossein Rohban', 'Mahdieh Soleymani Baghshah']
  • Tags: ['alignment', 'safety evaluation', 'adversarial prompting', 'model evaluation']

item.title: Cross-Modal Safety Alignment: Is textual unlearning all you need?
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper explores cross-modal safety alignment in VLMs by focusing on textual unlearning.
  • It shows that textual unlearning can reduce ASR for both text and vision-text attacks.
  • Multi-modal dataset unlearning is less effective and more computationally expensive.

item.description:

item.title: On Surjectivity of Neural Networks: Can you elicit any behavior from your model?
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper studies the surjectivity of neural networks, which relates to whether any output can be generated by some input.
  • It proves that common neural network components like pre-layer normalization and linear-attention modules are almost always surjective.
  • This implies that generative models like GPT-style transformers and diffusion models can generate any output, including harmful content.
  • The findings highlight inherent vulnerabilities to adversarial attacks such as jailbreaking.

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Haozhe Jiang', 'Nika Haghtalab']
  • Tags: ['surjectivity', 'neural networks', 'generative models', 'jailbreak vulnerabilities', 'adversarial attacks']

item.title: Malice in Agentland: Down the Rabbit Hole of Backdoors in the AI Supply Chain
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper explores backdoor vulnerabilities in the AI supply chain when fine-tuning agents on their own interaction data.

  • Results show that even 2% poisoned data can lead to successful backdoor triggers, and existing defenses are insufficient.

Paper Type
